section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build math background, engage children with movement, and introduce vocabulary (rhythm, pattern).
Start Story Time by introducing the book and asking, “What body parts are named in this story?”
Read for enjoyment, pointing out patterns.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize, complete, extend, duplicate, and create common patterns including A, B, A, B; AA, BB, AA, BB; and ABC, ABC.
Engage with trusted adults and peers to work, communicate, and play.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
React to a variety of musical styles through movement and play.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to recognize patterns using Connecting Cubes.
Challenge children to identify what color comes next in a pattern.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What are the parts of our body? What do they do?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What book did you choose? What is this book about?
Can you make up a dance? What is the rhythm of your dance?
Can you make a pattern? How do you know it’s a pattern?
Can you write song you love? What do you like about that song?
What patterns can you make with colors or shapes?
What letter does the word rhythm start with? Can you write that letter?
What pattern can you make with blocks?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder engage with adults and peers and introduce vocabulary (work).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to I Got the Rhythm.
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder and patterns.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize, complete, extend, duplicate, and create common patterns including A, B, A, B; AA, BB, AA, BB; and ABC, ABC.
Engage with trusted adults and peers to work, communicate, and play.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to invite partners to work together to create a pattern of movements.
Have children repeat a movement pattern.
Challenge children to share their patterns.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What are the parts of our bodies? What do they do?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Why did you choose that book?
Can you show how you and a friend can pretend together?
Can you make a new pattern? Can you show it to a friend?
Can you write about a time you worked together with an adult?
Why did you choose those colors?
What can you find in the room that starts with a B sound?
How can you add to what you are building to have a pattern repeat over and over?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. I Got the Rhythm by Connie Schofield-Morrison, illustrated by Frank Morrison. Text copyright © 2014 by Connie Schofield-Morrison. Illustrations copyright © 2014 by Frank Morrison. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Bloomsbury Children’s Books USA. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share a math strategy and practice identifying body parts with music.
Begin Story Time by revisiting I Got the Rhythm and asking the guiding question, How does the girl use her body parts to make a rhythm?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to review operations.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that adding or taking away one from a small group of objects changes the total quantity by one.
Recognize, complete, extend, duplicate, and create common patterns including A, B, A, B; AA, BB, AA, BB; and ABC, ABC.
Engage with trusted adults and peers to work, communicate, and play.
Ask and answer questions to seek help or information.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
React to a variety of musical styles through movement and play.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to recognize patterns in Connecting Cubes and observe how the number of cubes changes when adding and subtracting.
Challenge children to identify what color comes next in a pattern.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What are the parts of our bodies? What do they do?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What body parts are mentioned in that book?
How could you pretend to be a part of the body?
Can you make a five Connecting Cube train? How does it change if you add one cube? if you take one away?
Can you write about a part of the body?
Can you draw a creature that has more body parts than we do?
What is your favorite part of your face? What sound do you hear at the beginning of that word?
What would happen if you added one block to your building? What would happen if you took one away?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. I Got the Rhythm by Connie Schofield-Morrison, illustrated by Frank Morrison. Text copyright © 2014 by Connie Schofield-Morrison. Illustrations copyright © 2014 by Frank Morrison. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Bloomsbury Children’s Books USA.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Head, Shoulders, Knees, and Toes

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to review body parts and introduce vocabulary, (shoulders, knees).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts I Got the Rhythm and Head, Shoulders, Knees, and Toes.
Read interactively and connect to patterns by finding patterns and building on them.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize, complete, extend, duplicate, and create common patterns including A, B, A, B; AA, BB, AA, BB; and ABC, ABC.
Engage with trusted adults and peers to work, communicate, and play.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
React to a variety of musical styles through movement and play.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Create patterns for children using Connecting Cubes behind a curtain.
Challenge children to copy the pattern and then compare the two.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What are the parts of our bodies? What do they do?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Why do you like this book?
Which part your body would you use to act like a fish? A turtle? How are these animals the same? How are they different?
Can you make an ABAB pattern? What order do the blocks go in?
Write about two body parts. How are they alike? How are they different?
Draw your body. Why did you choose these colors?
What letter do you hear at the beginning of body? How can you make that letter?
Can you build a body or body part?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. I Got the Rhythm by Connie Schofield-Morrison, illustrated by Frank Morrison. Text copyright © 2014 by Connie Schofield-Morrison. Illustrations copyright © 2014 by Frank Morrison. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Bloomsbury Children’s Books USA.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photo © Dan Kosmayer/Shutterstock.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to connect to music and play a pattern game.
Start Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, Which body part do you like to use to make a rhythm? How?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize, complete, extend, duplicate, and create common patterns including A, B, A, B; AA, BB, AA, BB; and ABC, ABC.
Engage with trusted adults and peers to work, communicate, and play.
Ask and answer questions to seek help or information.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
React to a variety of musical styles through movement and play.
Respond to different musical styles through movement and play.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to the prompt: “What body part makes the best rhythm?”
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What are the parts of our bodies? What do they do?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What kind of book do you want to read next?
Pretend to have a new body part no one has seen before. What does this body part do?
How many Connecting Cubes would you add to repeat the pattern?
Can you write a story about a new body part?
Can you draw a picture of a pretend body part that doesn’t exist?
Can you make up a name for a pretend body part? What sound does it start with?
Could you build a tower with a pattern? What materials will you use?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize and create patterns.
Interact with a variety of playmates and may have preferred friends.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Participate in classroom music activities including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
Respond to different musical styles through movement and play.
Recognize and create patterns.
Interact with a variety of playmates and may have preferred friends.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Participate in classroom music activities including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
Coordinate sequence of movements to perform tasks.
Use concrete objects, create pictorial models and share a verbal word problem for adding up to 5 objects.
Use concrete models or make a verbal word problem for subtracting 0–5 objects from a set.
Recognize and create patterns.
Interact with a variety of playmates and may have preferred friends.
Provides appropriate information for various situations.
Participate in classroom music activities including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
Respond to different musical styles through movement and plays.
Recognize and create patterns.
Show competence initiating social interactions.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Coordinate sequence of movements to perform tasks.
Participate in classroom music activities including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
Respond to different musical styles through movement and play.
Recognize and create patterns.
Show competence initiating social interactions.
Interact with a variety of playmates and may have preferred friends.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Provides appropriate information for various situations.
Participate in classroom music activities including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
